notes: D-MOD only does business in size 6+ markets, as they don't have enough customers in worlds with a smaller population.

text:
You establish a linkup with the local D-MOD service center to seek out a representative.

D-MOD welcomes any spacers who offer their ships as target practice in any of D-MOD's weapon demonstrations. These demonstrations provide both entertainment to the local populace and a practical option for retiring captains wishing to cement their own decisions. Barring that, the more technical and savvy D-MOD employees seek out ships to creatively "modify", a desire largely satisfied by superstitious - yet wealthy - space captains who believe that a broken-down ship performs better than a pristine one.

After a short wait, a D-MOD representative establishes a comm-link with you to discuss their services and answer any queries you might have.

You establish a linkup with the local D-MOD service center to seek out a representative.

Despite operating within what they see as a controversial polity at best, the local Daedalia-Mariner Opis Demolitions employees seem to begrudgingly ignore this fact, as one of their representatives quickly establishes a comm-link to you, greeting you and willing to answer any questions about their services.

options: dmodservicesRandom:Offer one of your own ships as target practice
dmodservicesAutomate:Apply automated systems to a ship
notes: Option only appears if a certain [REDACTED] fleet has been defeated

options: dmodservicesSMods:Ask for special modifications removal on a ship
notes: Option only appears if the Usurpers questline has been completed
Going back to market main menu

id: # Go Back option (shared by all D-MOD options)

notes: Going back to D-MOD service menu

text:
You ask the D-MOD representative about using a ship from your fleet as target practice for their next demonstration. The representative gleefully accepts your interest, and they send a form to your TriPad regarding their Terms of Service.

Although whatever ship you offer would be effectively crippled after a D-MOD demonstration (albeit to the spectacular delight of onlookers), the D-MOD representative assures you that they will recover and return the ship to you, though with some permanent damage. However, they do offer some recompense in the form of credits, depending on the ship's initial hull integrity upon submission.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_credits $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSAddOptionConfirmation dmodservicesRandomConfirm "Confirm? The $DModServices_pickedShipName will be severely damaged and receive a number of random D-Mods."
SetEnabled dmodservicesRandomConfirm true
SetTooltip dmodservicesRandomConfirm "Disables the ship and applies a random D-Mod"
DMSAddDModSlider "Number of D-Mods" "Set the intensity of the demonstration and, thus, the number of D-Mods acquired afterwards."
text: The D-MOD representative calculates that you may receive at least $DModServices_credits as compensation for offering the $DModServices_pickedShipName.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesRandomConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesRandomConfirm "Ship cannot receive any more D-Mods from this service!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName, unfortunately, cannot be used as target practice, as it is far too damaged to remain recoverable after a demonstration.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSAddRandomDMod false
AddCredits $DModServices_credits
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName has received: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay" bad
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
DMSShowPlayerFleet
FireAll DModServicesRandom
text:
You have offered a ship to the D-MOD representative. An hour later, they invite you and your crew to their demonstration area, where you then find the $DModServices_pickedShipName sitting inert.

Soon after, a battery of Hellbore Cannons pound the helpless ship, forming a cloud of metal and fire around it. The barrage of explosions rock the demonstration area, shaking the ground beneath you and causing some of your crew to instinctually duck for cover. Once the Hellbore battery ceases and the smoke finally clears, you see the ship still barely-intact, wondering how it even managed to survive all of that.

As soon as you finish that thought, however, the ship's hull suddenly collapses onto itself, inciting cheers from the crowd of spectators as the presiding D-MOD employee formally ends the event.

Surprisingly, all the weapons fire have not completely ruined the ship, despite the heavy damage. Eventually, D-MOD engineers recover the ship to a usable state and send it back to you.
OR
You have offered a ship to the D-MOD representative. An hour later, they invite you and your crew to their demonstration area, where you then find the $DModServices_pickedShipName sitting inert.

Soon after, a Reaper-class torpedo slams into the lifeless hull, creating a nuclear explosion so powerful the protective containment fields visibly vibrate violenty, causing some spectators to scream in fear. Fortunately, the explosion eventually subsides, allowing an unobstructed view of the obliterated target: a heap of burning metal, providing a beautiful, warm light inside the demonstration area.

This spectacular event ends with the presiding D-MOD employee making an impassioned speech about the destructive beauty of the Reaper.

Surprisingly, all the weapons fire have not completely ruined the ship, despite the heavy damage. Eventually, D-MOD engineers recover the ship to a usable state and send it back to you.
OR
You have offered a ship to the D-MOD representative. An hour later, they invite you and your crew to their demonstration area, where you then find the $DModServices_pickedShipName sitting inert.

Soon after, a flash of light suddenly strikes the dormant ship, then another flash joins in the fray. Before long, the impressive array of ship-grade beams, ranging from modest Tactical Lasers to awe-inspiring Tachyon Lances, create a spectacular lightshow, to the delight of your crew and the other spectators - although the ship itself certainly isn't enjoying this at all.

At the end of this lightshow display, what was once a functional ship is now a steaming scrap heap, comprised of little more than the scarred and sliced-off pieces of its former glory.

Surprisingly, all the weapons fire have not completely ruined the ship, despite the heavy damage. Eventually, D-MOD engineers recover the ship to a usable state and send it back to you.
notes: Add random D-Mod to selected ship

text:
You ask about the D-MOD's specialized barratry services, knowing full well that they charge a hefty sum for such services. The D-MOD representative sends a request form to your TriPad, providing more details regarding this service.

A team of ship engineers would enter your ship to study its internals. Then, with the help of their own schematics and other proprietary machinations, these engineers will find the perfect way to break your ship such that it will only gain the damage you wanted and nothing more. Of course, such precise labor requires commensurate payment, especially when the ship has already been damaged beyond permanent repair.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_credits
SetTooltip dmodservicesSelectionPickDMod "Select compatible D-Mods to apply to the ship"
DoCanAffordCheck $DModServices_credits dmodservicesSelectionPickDMod false
text: The D-MOD representative calculates that the $DModServices_pickedShipName will require at least $DModServices_credits for a single modification.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesSelectionPickDMod false
SetTooltip dmodservicesSelectionPickDMod "Ship cannot receive any more D-Mods from this service!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName, unfortunately, cannot be damaged any further without risking a complete ship collapse.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_newCredits
DMSAddOptionConfirmation dmodservicesSelectionConfirm "Confirm? The $DModServices_pickedShipName will receive the following D-Mods: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay"
SetShortcut dmodservicesSelectionGoBack2 "ESCAPE"
AddText "Selected D-Mods: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay"
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
SetTooltip dmodservicesSelectionConfirm "Apply the selected D-Mods to the ship"
DoCanAffordCheck $DModServices_newCredits dmodservicesSelectionConfirm false
text: The D-MOD representative confirms that, with the planned modifications, the $DModServices_pickedShipName will require $DModServices_newCredits to fully service it.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSAddSelectedDMod
AddCredits -$DModServices_newCredits
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName received: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay" bad
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
DMSShowPlayerFleet
FireAll DModServicesSelection
text: You have sent your ship to the D-MOD's specialized engineers. Soon enough, your TriPad chimes with a notiifcation; the $DModServices_pickedShipName has now received its "special modifications"!
notes: Adds the selected D-Mod to the selected ship

id: # D-MOD option 3: Automate (requires discovery of a certain defender fleet)

text:
You ask if D-MOD's specialized technicians and engineers can automate one of your human-crewed ships. The D-MOD representative seems perplexed by your suggestion; they whisper to themselves about whether D-MOD is bound to the treaties signed between the Hegemony and the Tri-Tachyon Corporation during the two AI Wars.

After a short while, and to your surprise, the D-MOD representative requests that you provide them any data that would assist the service in creating automated ships. It seems this particular D-MOD center considers the profit made from complying with your request worth the off-chance that a zealous Hegemony AI inspector might inspect the center for "suspicious activity".

As you order your fleet technicians to transmit any and all data pertaining to automating human-crewed ships, the D-MOD representative warns you that such a specialized service comes with huge expenses - some of which, you suspect, may be used to pay off any potential AI inspections against the D-MOD center. Also, due to D-MOD's lack of documentation and experience, the automation process will not only inflict permanent damage on the ship, but the invasive - and highly complex - nature of this process will completely prevent any future ship restoration, making any ship damage incurred during and after the process permanent.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_credits
DMSAddOptionConfirmation dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Confirm? The $DModServices_pickedShipName will become fully-automated and receive a random D-Mod. In addition, the ship cannot be restored back to pristine condition."
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Automates the ship, applies a random D-Mod, and prevents any further restoration"
DoCanAffordCheck $DModServices_credits dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
text: The D-MOD representative calculates that the $DModServices_pickedShipName requires $DModServices_credits to fully-automate it.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship has too many D-Mods to be automated!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName, unfortunately, cannot be fully-automated, at least without turning it into a worthless pile of scrap.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship is already automated!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName is already automated and, thus, does not need any further specialist work.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship cannot be automated while you remain in command of it."
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName cannot be fully-automated while you still command it. You will need to transfer command to another ship before the automation can be done without undue risk.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship cannot be automated due to the officer in charge."
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName cannot be fully-automated while an officer still remains in command of it. For safety reasons, you will need to remove your officer in command of the $DModServices_pickedShipName before any specialized automation can be applied.

script:
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship cannot be automated due to the ship containing non-automated LPCs."
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName cannot be fully-automated while it is equipped with incompatible fighter LPCs. For compatibility reasons, you will need to unequip all modular, non-automated LPCs from the $DModServices_pickedShipName before it can be automated.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesAutomateConfirm false
SetTooltip dmodservicesAutomateConfirm "Ship cannot be automated due to an incompatible D-Mod or hullmod!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName cannot be fully-automated, as certain modifications, damaged or otherwise, within the ship completely interfere with any attempted automation retooling. You will need to restore the ship to a pristine condition - or else remove the offending modifications - before any automation work can be done.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSAddRandomDMod true
AddCredits -$DModServices_credits
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName has been converted to an automated ship!" good
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName has received: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay" bad
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName has been rendered unrestorable!" bad
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSShowPlayerFleet
FireAll DModServicesAutomate
text: D-MOD's best and brightest technicians and engineers have begun work on automating the $DModServices_pickedShipName. Before long, the $DModServices_pickedShipName is now fully-automated, its internal workings churning with the forbidden knowledge that had led to the First AI War. Not that anyone will stop you from exploiting this knowledge to its fullest extent, however.
notes: Applies the "Sentinel special" to a ship

text:
You ask the D-MOD representative if they offer any services for removing special ship modifications - which you clarify as non-standard ship upgrades, not the so-called "special modifications" normally offered by D-MOD. The representative then provides you with the Terms and Conditions regarding this exclusive service, available only to "those that prove themselves as a valuable partner".

D-MOD is well-known by spacers for their use of "deconstructive" methods, which also extends to disassembling unwanted ship modifications for captains feeling the "modder's remorse". D-MOD's team of expert ship mechanics and engineers can, with utmost precision and care, identify non-standard ship parts and tear them off the ship - all without causing any permanent damage to the ship.

Of course, like any worthwhile service, it will cost a pretty millicredit, or so the D-MOD representative says. You consider your options as you pore through the representative's TriPad.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_credits
SetTooltip dmodservicesSModsPickSMod "Select S-Mods to remove from the ship"
DoCanAffordCheck $DModServices_credits dmodservicesSModsPickSMod false
text: The D-MOD representative confirms that the $DModServices_pickedShipName will require at least $DModServices_credits to remove a special modification.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
SetEnabled dmodservicesSModsPickSMod false
SetTooltip dmodservicesSModsPickSMod "Ship has no S-Mods to remove!"
text: The D-MOD representative tells you that the $DModServices_pickedShipName does not appear to have any special modifications that can be removed.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_newCredits
DMSAddOptionConfirmation dmodservicesSModsConfirm "Confirm? The $DModServices_pickedShipName will have the following S-Mods removed: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay"
SetShortcut dmodservicesSModsGoBack2 "ESCAPE"
AddText "Selected S-Mods: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay"
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
SetTooltip dmodservicesSModsConfirm "Remove the selected S-Mods from the ship"
DoCanAffordCheck $DModServices_newCredits dmodservicesSModsConfirm false
text: The D-MOD representative confirms tha the $DModServices_pickedShipName will require $DModServices_newCredits to fully remove all the selected special modifications.

script:
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName
DMSRemoveSMod
AddCredits -$DModServices_newCredits
AddTextSmall "$DModServices_pickedShipName has lost: $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay" bad
SetTextHighlights $DModServices_pickedShipName $DModServices_pickedHullmodsDisplay
DMSShowPlayerFleet
FireAll DModServicesSMods
text: You have sent your ship to the D-MOD's team of starship engineers. Some time later, you receive a notification on your TriPad; the D-MOD engineers have removed the requested special modifications from $DModServices_pickedShipName!
notes: Removes the selected S-Mod from the selected ship
